snippet: The conflict in South Sudan is rooted partly in a failure to achieve a lasting reconciliation between rival factions when the country was created in 2011.
abstract: Analysts warn that conflict in South Sudan is rooted partly in failure to achieve lasting reconciliation between rival factions when country was created in 2011; instead of governing through strong institutions, many power brokers and generals still essentially command their own forces, their loyalties to government often determined by their cut of national oil revenues.

byline.contributor: Isma’il Kushkush contributed reporting from Khartoum, Sudan.

lead_paragraph: The conflict in South Sudan is rooted partly in a failure to achieve a lasting reconciliation between rival factions when the country was created in 2011.

headline.main: Old Rivalries Reignited a Fuse in South Sudan
headline.print_headline: Old Rivalries Reignited a Fuse in South Sudan
